register.translation[0].definitions[0].d: an official list of names of people, companies etc, or a book that has this list
register.translation[0].definitions[0].n: call/take the register British English old-fashioned (=say the names of the students in a class, to check who is there)
register.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Have you signed the hotel register?
Police want a national register of DNA samples.
the official register of births, deaths, and marriages
register.translation[0].definitions[1].d: the words, style, and grammar used by speakers and writers in a particular situation or in a particular type of writing
register.translation[0].definitions[1].e: letters written in a formal register
register.translation[0].definitions[2].d: the range of musical notes that someone’s voice or a musical instrument can reach
register.translation[0].definitions[2].e: the upper register of the cello
register.translation[0].definitions[4].d: a movable metal plate that controls the flow of air in a heating or cooling system
register.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to put someone’s or something’s name on an official list
register.translation[1].definitions[0].n: be registered (as) unemployed/disabled etc British English (=be on an official list of a particular group)
register.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The tanker is registered in Rotterdam.
The baby’s birth was registered this morning.
How many students have registered for English classes?
You must bring your insurance card with you when you register with a dentist or doctor.
register.translation[1].definitions[1].d: to officially state your opinion about something so that everyone knows what you think or feel
register.translation[1].definitions[1].e: The delegation registered a formal protest with US embassy officials Wednesday.
register.translation[1].definitions[2].d: if something registers, or if you register it, you realize or notice it, and then remember it
register.translation[1].definitions[2].e: She had told me her name before, but I guess it didn’t register.
I’d been standing there for several minutes before he registered my presence.
register.translation[1].definitions[3].d: if an instrument registers an amount or if something registers on it, the instrument shows that amount
register.translation[1].definitions[3].e: The earthquake registered 7.2 on the Richter scale.
register.translation[1].definitions[4].d: to show or express a feeling
register.translation[1].definitions[4].e: Her face registered shock and anger.
register.translation[1].definitions[5].d: to send a package, letter etc by registered post
register.translation[2].definitions[0].d: an official list containing the names of all the people, organizations etc of a particular type
register.translation[2].definitions[0].e: The Secretary of State maintains a register of those who have been disqualified from being company directors.
register.translation[3].definitions[0].d: to record a name or details about someone or something in an official list
register.translation[3].definitions[0].e: Transfers of shares will not normally be registered after the close of business on the record date.
people who are registered as unemployed
A new share issue must be registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
register.translation[3].definitions[1].d: to show or record an amount
register.translation[3].definitions[1].e: Hays Allen registered a 2.7% drop in fee income to £6.8 million for the year to 30 April.
